content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								A wonderful fishing game thats a little rough around the edges.This is an early access review of Fishing Planet. As of this writing, the game is currently on version 0.3.8 with an average update cyle of one every other week. I also have 400 hours in this title since August of 2015. I am a liesurely angler and have only recently reached level 21 in game.Fishing Planet is what I would consider a pseudo-simulator. The primary goal of the game is to relax and fish, though tournament style fishing is planned. As anyone who has fished in real life would know, you're never guaranteed a catch. This is the main point where Fishing Planet leaves the "true" simulation. It must balance gameplay with realism, and as such, catch rates are generally higher than what you would find in real life. On the other hand, you are offered a wider variety of rods, reels, lines, tackle, bait and misc. equipment designed to target a range of fish in a range of situations. You then couple all those decisions with your retrieval style, such as straight retrieves, stop and go, lift and drop, among others.That being said, what is planned and what we have currently are two different things. If you come into Fishing Planet at this time, expecting a perfect simulator, you will be disappointed. Fish currently have spawn boxes and set times when they spawn. Venture your lure outside this box or through this box at the wrong time of day and you won't find anything. Fish randomization is something the devs are working towards but, for the time being, the same general strategy is required. There are guides and spreadsheets detailing where to cast, when and with what lure/bait that will, hopefully, be rendered completely obsolete in the near future.There is a leveling system in place to limit where you can fish and what fish you can realistically catch. You can't just hop into the game and expect to catch 20kg Muskie immediately. You'll first need to catch smaller fish worth experience and credits to level up and purchase new gear, as well as licenses to higher tier lakes. The devs have recently ended a test in regards to removed level locks on lakes, and as such, it may be removed on all lakes in the future. If that's the case, your only limiting factor will be gear. You will still have to earn your gear by leveling up or bypassing level locks by purchasing DLC packs focusing on certain gear types such as heavy float rods or ultralight tackle. These DLC are completely optional if you wish to take your time and fish.Waterways are currently limited to North America, specifically, the United States. However, there are plans for European and Asian waterways in the future. Fish species are diverse and dependant on where you are. Current species include, but are not limited to Gar (Alligator, Florida and Longnose), Bass (Largemouth, Smallmouth, White, Peacock and Striped), Catfish (Channel, Blue, Flathead), Panfish (Bluegill, Crappie, etc.), Pike, Trout, Salmon and more.Graphically, the game is beautiful. Water physics are a sight to see. Ambient noise is great though some lakes can be a tad bit annoying to listen to.There are some rough spots though. They range from physics (fishing launching into the air) to fish AI bugs (fish don't even bother fighting on ocassion) to equipment bugs (drag exerting tension on the line even when not under any load). None of them are major or game breaking, in my opinion. Your mileage may vary. I currently would recommend this title to anyone who enjoys fishing as a leisure sport. Perhap, once tournaments are added, more competitive anglers will have something of interest. Arcade anglers, however, I fear would not find this fu. There are no easy-mode toggles such as underwater cam, reel assist, automatic tensioners or the like. If you don't know how to fish from real life experience and are unwilling to learn the basics of how fishing gear works, you may find this a difficult title to pick up.Just remember that this IS Early Acess, which means things are always changing. As such, don't get too comfortable with how things are. If something is easy to exploit, expect it to be changed, if there's a bug, expect it to be fixed.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								858 hours waiting to see  if this EA would finally take off and mirror the the boast of its creators. Sadly whilst graphically its 10/10 that is all it has going for it. As for realistic . Not even close. Now don't go on a hate rant I am evaluating the game on its description by the creators. Simulation od real life fishing. Come on guys who are you kidding it isn't even close. You cannot use the mosty used cliche "it's early access". Hooks that even Jaws would have trouble swallowing and floats normally used for mooring boats too. A game where every single facet is hinged upon the drag max on a reel!. How ridiculous.This game is doomed and it seems all the devs are interested in is putting more and more content in to a broken game. The rod reel physics have never worked from day one even if they have come a long way since the winch and haul method. Then comes  the cheaters  that were forewarned long before they arrived as in  all games some must win at any cost and pat themselves on the back for comfirming they are the lowest form of life breathing on the planet. How on earth do you expect to simulate a lake when there are no fish living in it. Spawn spots are not natural and are just pockets on a lake where 90% is devoid of any life. I played a 2D coded fishing game for 16 years and as a simulator it was spot on in every area and is still to this day the best fishing simulation ever produced.  It is a shame that despite describing themselves as fishing enthusiasts( reading between the lines meaning never picked a rod up in their lives) they do not posses the knowledge to make this game a worthy title. 6/0 hooks 30lb line with bloodworm as bait and being pulled all around the lake by a 15lb fish does that sond like a simulation of any fishing scenario any angler has ever had. The game is disjointed and a mess tbh. They are putting too many thumbs in too many pies and diluting what they have created. For a non angler it might occupy your time for a while but for any real life angler it's safer to stay on terra firma than engage this nonsense 2/10

From some of the stuff I read about this game it doesn't sound enjoyable to begin with. Paying for rod and reel repairs just to make players spend their in-game money, really? As an avid fisherman I can asssure you rods do not need to be "repaired" regularly if at all with special exceptions such as a broken tip or guide, and reel repair? Just oil and lube twice a year and most decent reels on the matket today will last a lifetime. I wish I could not reccomend this more than once, I understand this is a game but they are marketing it as a simulator, so lets at least simulate accuratly shall we? You can handle big fish just fine on light tackle unlike this game would have you believe, also I've seen several "tips" while sitting on the loading screen that are just flat out wrong. If you enjoy this game, hey go for it, but if the dev's are gonna market it as a realistic fishing sim they need to try MUCH MUCH harder.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								With almost a full day of gameplay I want to start a first impression review for people both in the know how for fishing and new to fishing games (like me. Yep, I'm a CSGO/Team Fortress player, not a simulator/fishing player. BUT I've fished in my life time): Pros:  This is the first game in a long time that has had me "hooked" extensively. The gameplay is fluid and accurate. Stepping into the game I was expecting 1 of 2 things: Confusing and unnecessary game mechanics OR pay for the "best" equiptment as do MANY other fishing simulators contain. Starting and Controls: BOY WAS I WRONG. Off the bat the tutorial gives you the need to know basics for fishing in general which is easy to use and from experience really an amazing portrail of the sport in real life. After you understand the simple and relaxing controls you're off fishing on your own. Gameplay: USUALLY, games like this would start you off with fish in tiers (Example: Start bluegill, then catfish, then bass, and so on). However, you're able to start going for either bluegill, catfish, pike, or bass right off the bat. When it comes to fishing in this game, real world knowledge is amazingly potent in this game. A HUGE plus over other fishing simulators! Catching a fish in this game gives a SUPER rewarding and that's why I'm enjoying every bit of the game play. Market Model: There are free to play games I play without spending a dime but are annoyingly hard and VERY long to progress through where I just get burnt out and stop playing. Then, there are games where a majority of everything in the shop can be achieved... PURELY BY PLAYING!You don't need to spend anything to achieve special currency. Yep, "premium currency" is awarded through achievments and special fish. Yep, just like the games of old, you can unlock special stuff just by playing the game! DLCs? PSSSSH. Though their DLCs give you and edge early on, you can completely farm up to get all the items in the DLCs just from playing.Also, the in game currency is made fast with a bit of work BUT no where near grindy or slow as many other F2P models out there. This game's F2P model is a HUGE plus being a F2P player. Great job!!! Cons:   Lack of Variety and Content: One thing that slows you down is the fact that there's only so many fish you can catch. To many people this can bog down grinding and cause interest to droop off but it's what I expect from a game that just went into release. I know for a fact there's going to be A LOT more content to be added here such as tournaments, quests, missions, and more fish and equiptment. Though on the plus side to this there are varients of the current fish you can catch and personally that's good enough for an on release game. Grindy(ish): Yep, Grindy. Big surprise there from a F2P game right? Well, as to be expected. Every game with progression has a grind but I feel like this game handles it fairly well to a point. Upon reaching lvl 15+ there's a huge gap in exp gain that causes the game to really slow down. However, this is in place so the level split between casual and hard core doesn't grow too far apart.In all honesty this is a good move to prevent inbalances when tournaments get released. I would like to mention this is changing a week after this post to increase exp gain all around. The low level grind is decent up until level 10 and then you feel the monotonous grind thereafter. Like I stated! They're changing this in a week so this will change for sure! Entry Level Steep(ish): If you have experience fishing or used to fish like me, then you'll be just at home here. Like I stated in the pros, this game is SPOT ON with relation to real life fishing.However, if you're completely new to fishing, you might have a hard time getting started since every single fish has their own way of being caught. Though this can be a problem for a little bit, there's PLENTY of guides on youtube, guides here on steam, and help in game. Verdict:  Honestly, I went in with expectations set by many failed misses in the fishing game genre from years before but I'm knocked on my♥♥♥♥♥with how well this game came to rise up to what has been sorely missing in this genre of gaming. The F2P market is both gameplay derived and not pay to win, the gameplay is spot on and rewarding, the graphics are beautiful as all hell, the physics are nice, and importantly to the genre, this game is really accurate.Though there are kinks here and there with lack of content and poor entry level, this game hit the spot for an alternative to FPS, RTS, and Strategy games that I'm used to playing.I really hope the devs continue to keep the game in the positive heading.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								This game is a conundrum. The graphics are beautiful, the effects like bugs skimming the water are stunning, the background ambience is incredible, and the actual gameplay stinks. They spent so much time making everything realistic looking that it feels like they forgot to allow time for the actual mechanics of the game. If you throw your line in the water and a fish bites at it, you have to wait for quite a while otherwise it says "strike too early" and you lose your bait. If you wait to long, it says something like "Strike timed out" and you lose your bait. The actual window, it seems, for being able to actually hook the fish is around 2.5 seconds out of the entire "strike zone". Add to that that it's nearly impossible to buy anything OTHER than bait like grasshoppers and worms and such, and when you can, you can't even use it because you can't buy the correct pole for lures, the game becomes infuriating. Wait to download this game until they actually fix the mechanics and make the game more open. After all, why should I wait until I'm like level 50 to be able to buy a particular fishing pole? Are they saying that in the real world, I can't buy a really nice setup unless I've been fishing for a long time already? No...a salesman will sell you whatever you want, even if you don't know how to use it.

number of helpful: 35 of 59 people (59%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWPros:Looks nice, graphics are fairly goodHas a more realistic look than most fishing gamesCons:First and foremost the game has a misplaced focus on locating fish rather than the catching of them.It can takes hours finding the right spot, time of day, right bait to find what your looking for and when you finally hook one, you can reel it in quickly without much trouble at all. The "fish fight" aspect of the game  is virtually nonexistent.The game claims to be "multiplayer" however is simply a single player instance with a chat box in the corner.No customization at all, any gear other than what rod and reel your using doesn't change your appearance at all, in fact you never see more than your own two hands.In its current state the game seems like little more than a tech demo, the maps are small, and it get repetitive rather quickly.VERDICT:I can't recommend the game at this time.The developers I think are dropping the ball, or what has been the case for many EA titles, the game is just a cash grab. They seem to prioritize how players earn experience over the fixing of major bugs in the game. In the first week of release they adjusted fish spawns and exp rate three times and have again since then. Balance in a game like this is important, however all these changes have been "nerfs" to experience gains to slow player progression. In a normal EA title this would be fine, however this one sells a premium membership in the cash shop that gives 50% bonus to experience. Early Access or not, if your going to have a cash shop people expect to get what they pay for and not have the game changed in a way that devalues what they purchased. Quite frankly the actions of the developers thus far throws up the   "cash grab" flags in my opinion.

You noticed I used the word supported cause I will never spend another dime on this game with the way things are now. I really feel like I just got crapped on. They removed items from the game that I paid money for. This so called upgrade to the Heavy Casting pack, Its not a upgrade its a peasment cause they took the 660lb Fish Net out of the game so you couldn't carry as much fish and would have too end your day sooner.  Thats fine but dont screw with something that I paid my money for.  If it came with the DLC leave it and figure something else out. The amount of money it takes to travel too and making it back while there has become way more difficult but not impossible if your willing to spend the money. But the licenses that you have to buy to fish there is completely insane. Adanced Unlimited License for Alaska is 1000 baitcoins. In the Premium shop 1090 bait coins will cost you 49.99.  All I can say is WOW WTF!  WIth the introduction of the 3D avatar's, that causes even more problems. For example in Flordia there are 3 small T docks to fish from and when you have 5 or more people standing there it's hard to see. All you see are fishing poles and fish flying in front of you.  These are just afew issues the game has now, there are many many more. With just these examples you should be able to see where this game is headed. But it will not cost you to download for yourself and give it a shot. Only thing I can think of is maybe they were bought out by EA.  If thats the case Origin's Vault is needing more games.

It's a grind fest, where you must play a whole day getting the same fish if you want to level up and get access other areas. It's not fun, it's boring as hell.EDIT: after some comments:I did not mean that i will get the same fish when i cast with specific bait/lure and on the specific spot. I mean you have to "grind" on the place that give a better, let's say xp/hour, in order to level up your account to get acess to new places/fishes. Trout are a example, i have some friends that spend the whole day getting trouts to gain a single level. And there are fishes that just dont "worth" the time because this exp system. I like to get all the fishes, but some species just dont worth the time you spend there.Another thing is that when i get a fish, i don't feel "rewarded". Fishes don't really fight, it's easy to get a trophy fish without even care taht your line may break. And since you learned, by yourself or saw any tutorial, how to get a specific fish, the AI of the game will always work on the same way. So if you cast on the same spot with the same lure in the same time (i heard that some uniques are caught exactly at the same minute of the day), you will get the fish. There is no "random" things that always happens on fishing irl. Some times you will get a fish on the "wrong" place and time and this don't happens here.Anyways, i read the last news and looks like they will improve exactly what makes me dislike the gamWhen this happens for sure i will change my review to positive, because the game overall is good.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 27
Early Access Review
								So I log into FP for the first time in a few months and see that I can travel to Canada again for the holiday. I also see there is changes with the way the game has money. I have 32k.... cool, I spend 4k on a license and 11k to get there. Well - when I try to pull out a pole - none. So I go to inventory and find nothing. I'm now assuming everything is gone.Not happy. I try to buy a new reel at 12k and a pole...not enough money.At this point, I'm really frustrated and irritated enough to quit and uninstall the game after a being around since it got on Steam. I bite the bullet and go home... only to find all my stuff there. Now I wasted all that cash.I'm writing because I'm at the point where I finally frustrated and hope you guys can fix it - maybe return the in game money I started with.....if not, it's been fun and well, I'd rather spend $20 for the game and not have a F2Pay kind of set up and may look at the Euro fishing game. I wrote to them on Facebook and the answer I got was lame:"Hello, every time you go fishing you have to make sure you have everything you need - from gear to lures etc, that works in real life, too.  We also stated in update notes that all gear has been moved to home.  Therefore we cannot do refunds, because nothing happened due to bugs. You can however go to a free lake and get yourself up & running there."I don't want to spend 5 to 15 minutes reading game notes of drastic changes. NEVER before did our inventory stay at home. We log in and our items were on our body and in our bags. Bad excuse. So - I'm uninstalling and will be looking at Euro Fishing or hell, I'll get a pole out in Minecraft and have a better time. What a shame. It's beatiful, relaxing and all that I like. This last patch for Freemium just blew it. Not going to dump money into another game like Planetside 2. I will pay the chunk ($10-50) up front and call it good from here on. Milking people for cash is lame anymore. Good bye Fishing Planet.

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								This game sadly turned into a cashgrab. Aside from the ultimate showstoppers: cooldowns and timers, there's just everything tweaked towards making you pay unless (unconfirmed) you set a VERY considerable amount of time aside. I haven't seen that though. So it might just be impossible for a working and living human.The game doesn't resolve around fishing. It's more or less an economy simulator set in the fishing scenerio. They have "travel costs", daily access fees, daily fishing licenses, gear upgrade costs, lure costs, bait costs... Everything costs, a lot.All that just to make you grind mindlessly by the way. Yes, there are other locations available, suitable to your "level" though.It kills the spirit of fishing. Fishing can be fun anywhere, not just in your "level zone".It also teaches you nothing. At all. It's just a gear show and a grind fest. What a missed oportunity.Instead of all the timer mess they could've just named a price (e.g. between 50-100€/$) where you can buy everything and be done with the cashgrab. But they didn'tAlso it seems they There would've been so much potential, for example VR. But sadly it seems the game is made for money, not because the devs actually like the sport.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								A great game, with a great community, however a horrible moderator who doesn't believe in or allow freedom of expression within Forums.The Good: Good graphics with varied fishing locations and species of fish. There are plenty of fish to be caught and plenty of locations to catch them, the developers have done a good job of try to emmerse you in the game play.Great community, every time that I have had a problem or not understood things the other players have taken their time to help give advice, point me in the right direction, and in general to be pleasant and helpful.Game play, at first things can be a little confusing and even a little over whelming in the choices or rod, reels, baits, lures hooks, etc..,, however with a little effort and a few questions asked a person can have a well balancd set up and be catching trophy fish and unique fish.The Bad.No freedom of speech within the forums. Even if your post violates none of the Steam Rules or the rules of Fishing Planets forums the modrator refuses to allow open and honrst debate regarding the game or any problems encountered while playing the game. If it varies from his opinion you will be banned.Sounds, the sounds seemed canned and antiquated. The dove sounds like a whistle kids make by blowing into their hands.Not enough communication from developers. Not much more can be said on this topic. without communications the user feels left out and abandoned. Synopsis. A very good game that is fun to play and a great break from blowing stuff up all the time. After a long days work the game is a great way to relax and enjoy fishing at home. Whether you buy content or use what you are awarded as you level up, the game is a blast. The best gaming community I have seen in a very long time. Definitely worth the time to check out.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would not recommend this game for anyone except maybe the people who like mini games. The graphics were okay, water had some problems and its a fishing game so it's important. Real water doesn't just move up in one spot about ten feet while its a still lake and there wasn't any point where you could actually see the fish in the water even if the water was crystal clear, which is my favorite part about fishing is seeing the fish in the water. Before I even downloaded the game, I read and met all of the minimum requirements, and even all but one of the recommended requirements and when I log in the game says I dont even meet minimum requirements. My computer isn't a bad laptop or anything I bought it specifically with high graphics games in mind and put quite a chunk of money into it and before I even start playing this game tells me You dont have the minimum requirements and the game is going to glitch out on you. Get into game and all of the controls are screwed up the tutorial spent ten minutes telling me to press one button while the actual button that I had to go hunt and peck looking for was across the keyboard. After that shenannigans I get past the tutorial and get into a private room and I cant move because the game keeps telling me I dont meet the minimum requirements. After a week of constant failures on this game I just gave up even trying. Ive had better fishing experiences in my pool to be honest and would rather play any of the major console fishing games before I deal with this. I understand that its early access but usually you include the tag Alpha Test or something on your steam page so that people know its going to be terrible to play and you're honestly going to spend about an hour working through glitches.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								Right now this game has 13 DLC packs, totaling approx. $285, but this game is free-to-play apparently.I can buy 4 triple A titles at release (and have change) with the total cost of the DLC, and this game absolutely does not equate to 4 titles.Prices have been inflated (they haven't scaled; everything is actually more expensive) and perm. licenses now require currency that as of right now can only be bought, or scrounged up over dozens of competitions. (assuming you place) Some licenses alone cost $50. (Alaska)The new, insidious, and exploitative economy is designed to push players to just buy DLC and premium currency instead of playing the actual game. I would argue that the game, as of 0.70 is as - or even more difficult, than it was when it first released. In the 2 years this game has been out, The dev's promise to deliver a quality free-to-play experience has manifested into a trap to sate their greed. Fishing Planet is taking advantage of its monopoly on the fishing simulator niche here on Steam, and it's disgusting. It is a former shell of the principles by which it was founded, and I find the avarice of the developers appalling.   The developers do not derserve to be rewarded with your money or your time for their deceptive practices. Stay away.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game. Caters to the outdoorsman, as well as the MMO player. Which I happen to be both. Has many aspects of great mmorpgs, level progression, gear upgrading. As you level up you unlock access to new livewells, rods, reels, lines, lure, bait, and fishing equipment. The leveling is at a good pace, and the money system is NOT pay to win. You get cash for every single fish you catch, you also get experience. While I've never put 1$ into the game, I consider myself pretty decent at it. It's all about finding the right spots to fish, and using the right gear, as well as different techniques to control your lure. The fights are exciting and nailbiting at times. When you just know you have that trophy fish on the line,and you don't want him to unhook. Also, there is unique fish, and Trophy grade fish, which will give you very huge rewards, unique fish also give you money for the cash shop, which you also recieve a chunk every time you level up,and the reards increase every level. If your not sure about it, JUST TRY IT, us gamers need to support these developers who think outside the box and make great games. This is true progress in gaming, not another copy and paste sword and board, or korean grinder. This is where its at, you must try! Look me up when the friends list goes live and let's nail them! Name:MASIKRDEMFISH

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								F2p done right here. Even right now in early point of the Early Access, without much to do, other than grind experience and chat with other players at your fishing spot, this game truly shines brighter than the other fishing sims and games I have played so far.So many rods and lures to choose from, with different kinds of lines and reels , its really the fishing game to try out.Even at this point there are good amount of spots and a lots of different fish types to choose from.I personally love the leveling system, and the unlocking of better equipment and clothes through ranking up while fishing. Cant wait for the tournaments, quests and duels which are coming on a later date into the game. They will make the relaxing fish grinding even an better experience for us in the future.And about the microtransactions.This game definitely isn't another TheHunter, if you know what I mean. You can easily play and enjoy this game for full of its content for free and enjoy it as much as anyone. The ingame currency is easy to obtain and gets you the gear and licenses you need for the fishing spots without too much work (Or work at all, cause its fun to earn ingame currency while fishing and turning the fish in). If you are interested in fishing or just fishing games, I cannot recommend this game highly enough for you.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me star this off by saying I am one of those that is VERY lery of F2P games. Its not that I have an issue with the sales model.....If done properly it works very well for some games. But thats where it all falls apart, because 9 times outta 10 it is NOT done properly. To many games say F2P but then hide huge amounts of content behind paywalls. To many say F2P but are actually P2W.......And EVERYONE here Im sure know full well what I speak of....I could name games but would rather not....That having been said......This is a great game, and a GREAT F2P model. Even the DLC on steam is mostly stuff that you can get ingame playing without ever paying a cent (or there is comparable from what I saw).I have not purchased any of the DLC yet but I plan to, seems a great way to stock up on role specific gear AND this honestly has potential to be best fishing sim ever..Im willing to throw some $$ at that!!!I have purchased the 3 day premium account. Can say these packs or more than reasonably priced for what you get..and brilliant you can use your steam wallet for this!! I did level to almost 4 before getting premium to get a feel for the game. Yes it is a bit slow...but its fishing, everything is a little slow ya =) It did not seem to slow or unfair or overly grindy at all.Great game thats 100% playable with ZERO investment, but well worth every penny if you do decide to spend a bit.

number of helpful: 19 of 34 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pros:- The graphics for the tackle and other items are well done. When you buy items from the bait shop or pro shop it looks like you're actually purchasing a real item.- The environment graphics aren't perfect but they are nice.- The imposed limit of what you can buy when on a fishing trip is interesting. You are limited to buying small things like extra bait or line but if you need a better rod you have to cancel the trip. It makes planning crucial.Cons:- There are certain combinations of items to catch certain fish, and certain spots to catch them. There is very little variety other than the size, length, or quality (trophy or non-trophy) of the fish once you figure this out.- Bugs and unrealistic physics. Sometimes when you cast you will just drop the line into the water at your feet. I was told by many other players that they experienced this bug. If you yank a fish out of the water sometimes it will send it into this ridiculous orbital spin where it goes sailing around your body. I ended up not having to struggle with fish anymore because I would yank them from the depths of the river and they would go flying into the sky and right up on the riverbank where I could just reel them in as they sat there.- Two forms of currency. A lot of items in the game can only be bought with gold. You can earn it without any form of micro-transaction but it just doesn't make sense. When did you ever go into a Bass Pro shop and try to buy something with gold coins? These aren't always things like special rods or reels...they are consumables like grasshoppers...- No weather effects.- Poor day and "night" cycle.- There really is no multiplayer in this game. You fish by yourself and you can chat with other players but you never see them in-game.-  Extremely limited by fishing locations. You can only travel the space of about 20 feet along a bank or dock to change where you fish. You won't be finding any secret fishing holes. Part of the fun of fishing is exploring and finding your own spot.

								This makes me happy. Way more happy than most games I currently own. Sure its not for everyone, but few things are. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fishing Planet was a good romp for a while. The grind set in pretty hard after Colorado however. Even with recent XP bumps, there didn't seem to be any reason to visit the next area. North Carolina had more spots for snags, less XP, and generally less progression than Colorado. So you're faced with the prospect of grinding out three+ levels of trout instead of feeling like you're getting somewhere by moving on to the next area. I skipped the (somewhat miserable) New York area entirely after a couple of trial runs there.But if you can ignore the grins and stick to the starter area and Colorado, you'll see what a beautiful, relaxing game it is. You can certainly kill some time and drink a few beers, maybe even kindle your interest in real life fishing. But unless there is vast improvement in the progression, don't let it become a major time sink. Just enjoy the good stuff, and hope the bad areas get better.

content:
Posted: January 31
Early Access Review
								At this time, I feel that this is a freemium game that requires paying to enjoy, and the price seems quite high to be honest.  I normally like to support devs that are working hard on making an awesome game; however, for a reasonable price.  It is not for casual players, unless you don't mind fishing at a single lake that my circle has begun calling noob lake.  Everyone in the game is now from Texas, and that is the only lake you can reasonably fish until you are at least level 16 when you can get decent sized nets.I have calculated the cost of going to the next level location, which is Missouri, and it takes a minimum of ~20 lbs of the most profitible fish in the area, large mouth bass to break even, but only if you spend baitcoin (the in-game premium currency) to get an advanced license permanently.  The good thing is you can earn some baitcoin through achievements, leveling, and by logging in every day for a bonus (every 5 gives 1 baitcoin).  So getting these licenses is not impossible, just takes a loooong time if you want to stay free.If you have plenty of time to grind fishing noob lake, then go for it.  If you really like fishing, get bored easily in the same spot, but don't have a lot of time to play (like me), then stay away.  If you are a hard-core fishing nut and don't mind paying quite a bit of real-world money to do whatever you want to do, then this game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you want a fishing game this is the only one you need. People complaining about grinding? It's fishing, it's fun and it takes patience and getting to know what the fish like. You'll be able to start catching fish right away without that, but if you really want to be able to catch the a trophy or catch a unique fish then you'll need to do your homework.The community is very friendly and willing to help you out regardless of your knowledge of the game and it's the first online community that has been able to elicited a smile during the hours of playing over the last few days. If you don't have a little patience or a little drive to try and figure the fish out then the game isn't for you. All the information is pretty easily available and there are plenty of guides on the steam forum and within the game itself if you ever get stuck. The gear choice is a little overwhelming at first, but you pick it up quickly.

Early Access Review
								So far a very promising game. There is a lot of potential here and the devs claim to have realism at the fore-front of their minds. Realistic game that will get you addicted quickly. content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								This game presents a good concept, is a realistic simulator, but with many bugs and a bad support.  Title Fishing Planet   Developer Fishing Planet LLC.   Publisher Fishing Planet LLC.  Release 11 August 2015  Graphics 3D   Genre Fishing Simulator  Price Free-to-play  Rating  4/10 The game.Fishing Planet is a sportsfish simulator that places players at various locations across the United States. Cast your line and catch a huge variety of fish, using an assortment of equipment in a soothing, realistic experience.Gameplay.There are 32 fish species, a huge assortment of fish swim in the waters of Fishing Planet, from catfish to pike.There are 7 locations. You can travel across North America and fish in varied environments, taking advantage of weather conditions to reap the largest number of fish you can.The equipment seems unrealistic. Is the equipment designed to wear off? Great idea to spend money. It was the worst update that could have come out.One aspect that I really enjoyed it was the relaxing atmosphere. While you fishing, you are involved in a soothing and relaxing atmosphere.This game crashes for no reason all the time, it's frustrating. And sometimes, your basket of fish will be empty for no reason and will not give credit for what you have worked for, on a crash.If it's of your interest, there is another known fishing simulator-game: Euro Fishing.Bad support of developers(?)Well, I saw some answers of the developers to some negative reviews of players with so many hours and...I was stunned.  The idea with which I was stayed is that developers don't want to know about the community, at all. They still give you bans, and bad answers. Amazing.No, for me this doesn't work.Pros. (+)Concept.Relaxing atmosphere.Decent graphics.Cons. (-)Basic bugs.Menu crashed a lot of times; you basically are forced to quit playing over a half hour, every hour. Ridiculous.Developers.Sad, because the game has potential. But even the best game ever can't develop without a good support.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright im gonna make this review quite short at the moment because i haven't really got that far into the game when i write this. First and formost i gotta say.. Wow.. This game.. If you fish in real life and love it this game will pull you in and keep you playing! This is one of the most realistic and fun fishing games ive played in a LOOOOONG time. You actually gotta use real tactics, use the right lure/bait, right rod, line and depth. This is not some arcade game where you just throw out a lure or a bobber with some bait and just catch fish.. But that's the best part in my opinion :)Many of you that has seen theHunter for example on steam might think "oh is this one of those games where you have to pay real money for licenses (Yes there are licenses in this game but ALL of em can be bought with ingame cash even unlimited ones so you don't have to keep paying every time you wanna fish. And keep in mind if you buy a license for  example 1 day it will actually last for 24 in real life hours)For now this is a wellcrafted, fun and very realistic fishing game with ALOT of potential to be one of the best ones out there. With more updates coming (boats, saltwater fishing more lures, baits and fish) this game will keep me busy for a very long time :) And don't let the bluegill "farming" let you down in the begining :P It really opens up after level 3. Bass fishing is extremly fun! :D I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves fishing :) A big thanks to the devs for their hard work trying to keep the servers stable and pushing updates at the same time :)

Early Access Review
								This game has serious bugs.  It runs badly at the best of times.  It is also extremely difficult to enjoy the more interesting places in the game unless you spend cash on content.  I don't have a problem with spending on a game, but not when it has this many flaws.  Bugs are a very serious and legit problem issue with game play.  Expect to have to close and reload this game multiple times while playing.With all the bad, the game has serious potential.  I have been waiting for a legit fishing game for a long, long time.  This almost gets it.  Probably the best I've seen for incorporating action in the bait.  Most fishing sims before just were a straight retrieve more or less.  Others were also too arcade like.  I think that is what disappoints most.  They have all the elements, just failed to put the pieces together right.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								As I reeled in what felt like my millionth .4 pound bluegill last night, I realized "wow, if I were fishing for bluegill in real life with worms right now, I'd sure to be catching more than just them!" This game has great mechanics as far as the catching of fish, casting lines, watching for a strike, etc..  But the grind as it stands now is just horrible.  In reality, no arbitrary level of experience blocks me from catching different species.  I really wish the game would throw a few line-breaking bass, pike, and catfish into the mix while you're still in the newbie phase of catching freight train loads full of bluegill.  I also wish it would let you advance beyond bluegill/crappies more quickly, as I'm bored with these two species of fish.  The sizes of fish really don't vary all that much, either.  I'd like to see some 10/12oz bluegill, some trophy pounders, and some itsy-bitsy ones that you have no idea how they took the bait in the first place.Other than that, I am definitely excited for the future.  This is an early access game, and a free-to-play one at that.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've played a bunch of steam games, never done a review before. This game however is worth my time to say all the nice things I can about it. Graphics are great, game play is fun and intuitive, keeps me coming back. Very enjoyable community thus far. Imersive enviroments. All good games, in my opinion have leveling systems and an inventory, gain 2 types of currency from catching your fish in addtion to experence. Yep, that's awesome. As far as the inventory system...  well you get a "backpack"(i.e., vests, rod cases, tackle boxes) full of tackle and rods as well as a garage at home that you can fill floor to cieling with everything from the shop. Tons of options for tackle,rod,reel setups and they are not even close to being done releasing gear... So yes...  Fishing Planet is amazing, travel the country and catch fish with us. This game is a complete gem, and the devs are doing an amazing job polishing it. If you like fishing, have an interest in fishing, ever been fishing..... PLAY THIS GAME.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
Newbie Review: Fishing PlanetHello everyone! This is my first review ever for a game on Steam, and I do intend to get better at it as I continue reviewing my favorite games, so don't be too harsh on me, OK? WARNING: A lot of text ahead! Please skip to TL;DR if you're not into this kind of reviews.This game popped up on Steam, and my first thought was "A Free-to-Play fishing MMO? What's that?". This game was free to download so I decided to give it a try. This game is in Early Access  so many features are absent at the moment but the core gameplay and the main mechanics of the game are absolutely clearly visible and I like them a great deal already. The game has a small but concise and precise tutorial, and a hint system was added recently so anyone new to the game in particular or to the genre as a whole will have a decent possibility to dive right in without any significant problems. In my first 30 minutes or so of gameplay, I realized that getting experience and unlocking new equipment was quite hard and similar to a grind of some kind, but the developers are constantly working on the game and they did improve the experience gain system, leveling up become easier even without a premium account (I hadn't put any money into this game up to this point and I think it won't be necessary at any point in the near future, and this I also like a great deal). This game does require a little bit of fishing knowledge to get the full experience out of it. However, this doesn't mean you have to be a fishing expert to play this game properly. I went fishing (IRL, I mean) a couple of times so I have some basic information about where to search for fish, what bait to use and so on. So, from a casual gamer and a newbie fisherman standpoint, this game is quite easy to understand, very chill and relaxing (awesome graphics and sound effects do get the work of chilling you out done quite nicely), and of course it is reasonably entertaining. As of the moment of this review being posted, there are no multiplayer components in this game aside from the chat (which, to be frank, I haven't even used yet), but it doesn't take a lot from the game in its current status.As of right now, this is more of an enjoyable single-player fishing sim than an MMO, but the game is still quite good. Controls in this game are quite intuitive and also there is a full key binding map available if you press F1 in-game.I have very little to say about the negative aspects of this game, but there are some nonetheless. First and foremost, you have a limited amount of fish you can catch and carry away (in other words, your storage capacity is limited, just like IRL), but there is no clear indication  on the interface itself of whether you have storage capacity left or not. You have to go to your inventory and check that from time to time. In my opinion, it would be more comfortable to see your storage capacity indicated, for example, in the left hand bottom corner of the screen. The second  annoying thing in this game is that your hook may get stuck, the popup says you can free the hook, but out of 10 cases of being stuck I didn't manage to get my hook back. It's either an annoying bug or my hands just being not straight enough (which is indeed a possibility when it comes to gaming).Now, I quit this extensive babbling, and get straight to the TL;DR SectionTL;DRPros:- awesome sound and graphics- intuitive controls- relaxing gameplay- true F2P, very few premium items- constant improvements in the gameCons (those will hopefully get fixed)- no multiplayer just yet- your hook often gets stuck and you have to cut the line most of the time- no indication of spare storage capacity directly on the HUD, it may be usefulDo I recommend this game? If you are into fishing or fishing simulators and want to relax a little bit, then give this game a try right now. You will need to play about 15 to 30 minutes after you have completed the tutorial to make your mind about this game in its current state. Bear in mind that it will get updated. And I also may need to update my review if the devs introduce some major changes (which they hopefully will).P.S. If you have time and desire to do so, please give your feedback on what I need to do in order to improve my reviews. Healthy and reasonable criticism is also very much accepted. ))

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a pretty fun fishing game.  Can be a bit grindy, but it's enjoyable and relaxing.  If you're looking for a chill experience in a game of skill, this one is for you.Graphically it's pretty decent.  I don't have any issues with it on my machine, and find it faily bug free for the time being.  You get the odd lag spike every now and again, but other than that I haven't noticed anything game-breaking.A few things I'd like to see:Additional Weather Effects.  Rain would be a nice addition.  Wind would also be a good simulation addition to add to the challenge of placing your cast.Better social aspects.  Friends lists would be cool.  A guild system (fishing clubs?).  A slighty improved interface for going over your equipment.  It'd be nice to easily compare items to one another on mouse-over...like a hover box when you look at something in your inventory to compare to what you have currently equipped.  That's my two cents for now.  Back to the water for me.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Pros:  Most realistic fishing game to date.  Think "The Hunter" but with a higher moisture content.Very active Devs that listen to the community and actually seem passionate about fishing.Wide range of fish from bluegills to bass to pike and everything between.  Muskies in the future.Simple but effective casting/retrieving systemCons:Fish "hot spots" are all you need to know, cast same area over and over againGrind - you'll find yourself casting the same spot over and over landing fish over and over to levelLocations limited at this timeMost of those cons should be fixed once they add more locations and boats.  Being limited to a few shore spots at this time really causes a lot of repetition but once you can float around the lake that should make things much more interesting.If you like fishing you will like this game.  If you don't like fishing you might find this game boring at its current build but in the near future things look to be really opening up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I once caught a Catfish with just a string, a hook and a bait. So I always wanted to somehow find a Fishing game that's just as simple and realistic as it is. So I played this game. Let's just say in a nutshell:> Catches fish using non F11> Feels like worst fishing casting method ever....> Asks silent fishermen in the area.(You can't see them around but they are fishing invisible to you actually).> Random fisherman tells me to press F11.> F11 allows me to throw max or control where I throw the bait/lure to.> Was grateful as f**k because game turned to Game Of The Year Edition for Fishing.> Then asked where to fish other kind of fish(Since I always got nub fish)> Random Fisherman told me step by step on how.> So I followed and I got my 1st catfish by using just Bread.>After getting a 3.4lb Catfish, I (Accidentally) bragged I can't keep it, since its too big for my fish keeping tool. Random Fisherman says, 'Nevermind, still nice catch!' "Laughed Internally" > Later on, suddenly we talked about MLG Fishing while waiting for my bait to get bite. We talked about 360noaimcasting 2ez and I actually tried 360 casting like a pro and got a fish from it(took some time still).>LATER ON, We talked about DLC in a good way. Someone suggested if they can have a radio, but there's already Steam Music Player lol. I recommend an announcer DLC where if someone is fishing something big they'll go announce it like how a sports announcer does in an exaggerated way. However other people suggests even more ridiculous DLC ideas. Well.....what can I say? It's a simple, calm, fishing game, that takes some knowledge(Well after you look at some guide or yt vids that is), and patience by the shore, encompanied by some noises near the river bank, like small critters like crickets and bees, near your ear with the sound of the river flowing and mists and daylight transitions. 13.5lb/10lb will fish this amount of fish again every day. Hope someday I can fish a shark or megalodon in a DLC.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11
Early Access Review
								On the surface, the game is superb. It has great mechanics, lots of content and good features for competition, highscores, etc. If it can sort out the technical issues, it will be miles ahead of the competition. As it is now, it's a really high potential, high frustration experience.The server issues are the most frustrating. Inventory items disappearing- or not appearing in the first place, scores not registering all seem very common. Since the community is built around these features, it's just not working right now. These are also the kind of things you won't really notice until you've already invested a lot of hours in the game. The game is relatively new on Steam, yes. But as I looked through forums, it seems players have been reporting the same issues now for a couple of years. If it takes a couple of more years to fix the infrastructure, the game will be dead or another game will take its place. Which would be a great shame.The monetization is very hardcore. The server is unstable. The game itself is great, but turns more and more painful the longer you play it. Hope it will change.

								I've played almost every fishing game ever.Fishing Planet = 9/10. Will surely be the best fishing game available once they add everything else, boats, kayaks, new locations, tournaments, etc.This game is for true simulation/realism lovers. You hear the grass, trees, just the right bugs, the water, your rod and reel, wind, air, nothing else. Reminds me of heading out to Granny and Poppies old farm house, catching grasshoppers and fishing the pond, or fishing under the bridge out by Snow Hill Road for bass and catfish with my buddies. I really miss bass fishing back home, this game gives me my fix! I have played almost every fishing game ever created. I'm a die hard. This one is by far the best. Not for arcade fishing lovers. This is the real simulation of fishing.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fishing Planet is a fishing simulation sport game, where you play as a fisher and buying licenses to different regions and catching different fishes, either SP, MP or co-op cross platforms.First of all, the game spare you the smell of fish, and secondly you get the game for free. The game offers a perfect overview of a fishing experience while thinking about life. The game starts to throw you through a tortorial, how to fish, what kind of bait to use and many other advanced fishing techniques.You will have a inventory as player, where you can move around the fishing spots or travel by plane to find and catch better fish at better locations. You have the option to change time according to best time of catching fishes etc. When you catch a fish you can either release it or keep it to gain a reward. The reward is being used to buy better bait and other equipment. You do have a option to buy ingame cash for real time money, to get better equipment to catch better and bigger fishes.For a free game, with a bunch of DLC's, the game offers a great fishing simulation sport game for those who loves fishing or wishes to learn about it. So if you are sitting with a fisher feeling in your stomach and want to learn something or relax in your home and run away from the fish smell, then this game is for you. Here is a demo:

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is probably the single most greatest achievement in my life. I have never played a more perfect game. To the way you cast, to the astmosphere, this game has it all. The world looks beautiful as I stand by the water casting my line, and then I get a bite! I reel it in a little, let it pull, and then pull it out of the water! I've never experienced anything like it before! There is even a multiplayer part to the game! You can fish with all of your friends! As you all fish in the same area you can see what everyone else is catching around you! My friends and I all had a blast sitting here one rainy night, all fishing together. It was a great experience and I hope that everyone else comes and joins us too! And if that wasn't enough to get you to get this game, then perhaps me saying that its free will get you to come and try it out! Plus the game is super easy to get into! Even those that don't like fishing can simply walk around the beautifullly constructed world. I can't wait to see you all down by the pond!

Eurotruck FishingSo after tackling few days with the infinite loading screen and getting a helpfull tip to turn off my firewall, i decided to try and add the game to my Allowed list and it worked! so i was finally able to get ingame.Now i been playing few fishing games here and there since the 90s and i quite weirdly enjoy random fishing game moments and was hoping "Fishing planet" would give me an good experience and it sure didGood:+ Fancy graphics (The game sure is an eyecandy)+ Crazy selection of equipment (i was blown away how much fishing stuff you can buy from lures to rods to hooks... it clearly shows the developers passion to fishing)+ Relaxin (its oddly nice to just sit on a pier and wait for the fish to start nippling on your baits)Bad:-No music during gameplay (this really isint a downside since the natural sounds of birds is kind of relaxing but i would hope in the future there would be a choise for somekind of FM radio to listen random songs and/or proadcasts while spending quality time on fishing)For anyone that is looking for fishing game or just to relax and spend time i can highly recommend this.

								At first, my thoughts were "why on earth am I playing a fishing game when I don't even like fishing?". However, I quickly began to realise that the people who play this game are all really nice and they all seem to contribute to the fun, relaxing atmosphere of the game. In my opinion, Fishing Planet has a lot of potential, perhaps as a game perhaps aimed at an older audience, and could even attract people who are inexperienced in fishing, such as myself, by going into more detail in explanations and tutorials, etc. Overall, I'd say give it a try if you want a relaxing and peaceful experience, and if it's not your thing then just uninstall it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
Early Access Review
SummaryFree to play but works best with a quite expensive premium account. As a simulation it's quite amazing with different types of fish having different habits, preferring different baits, and each kind can vary greatly in size. You really need to plan your approach and know your trade to be succesful. Definitely not that easy to learn and pretty hard to master. I can easily recommend this one, if you are prepared to buy premium, at least in the beginning, to level up a bit and have more fish to choose from.Pros1. It's free so you can check it out for yourself. 2. There are many different kinds of fish, including normal, young, trophy, and unique variants. Each fish has its habits and preferences so you can't use the same approach all the time, you must really tailor it accordingly.3. While premium account really helps a lot, it is not a requirement as there is no way to simply buy levels or high-level equipment without hard work. Premium speeds it up significantly, but if you are patient enough, you will achieve the same thing. The main hindrance of not having premium account is cash - you really need to make your stay in each state profitable and this is much harder without premium account and lower prices for fish that you catch, especially on lower levels. 4. Graphics are pretty good.5. Community is really friendly and other players can tell you how they are so succesful using in-game chat. I have not encountered even one instance of real rudeness. 6. There is a lot of gear to choose from allowing a lot of customization. 7. You can always check which fish are available at each lake, along with what to catch them with.8. There are a lot of decent guides on Steam and YouTube so you can learn the ropes without too much trouble. 9. The game is pretty stable and I haven't encountered any game-breaking bugs. 10. I love the travelling system. You can't just go anywhere you please, you have your home state, and each trip costs some money - you really need to plan them well to make them profitable, especially at lower levels. 11. You can still catch quite a lot of fish, contrary to most reviews here, it just takes skill and luck. I can catch 35 lbs of catfish in about 15 minutes, although I never really counted it, and I don't have a very high level, nor DLC or baitcoin gear. Cons1. There are some graphical glitches, like people warping across the lake, but nothing annoying. 2. Premium account is pretty expensive.3. Rooms are small, I would love to play with more other people, exchanging experiences and competing. 4. Weather changes are definitely not subtle. Note - I do have a premium account, I bought baitcoins once, and own no DLCs.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								While the beginning is pretty boring what with catching Bluegills and all, it's worth it to get to level three so you can start using lures.  Bass and Catfish are possible at level 2, but you'll probably catch more Bluegills than anything.  Once you get some spoons and jigs, the real fun begins and levelling goes much faster from there.  I sat down with a six pack of beer and before I knew it a couple hours had passed and I was out of beer.I like that the game tries to teach you proper fishing techniques, which you can then apply to real world fishing.  I've learned a few things and will try them out next time I get on a boat because shore fishing in my area is pretty poor.  Overall it's a great game with lots of potential.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm an angler in real life and I play games as well, so I can review this game from both perspectives.As a fishing sim: this sucks balls-the listed species for each fishing location lie; there are only 6 species shown when there may be more and it says, for example, "pike" or "trout" instead of the actual species like "grass pickerel" (which is a member of the "esox", or pike, family)-getting snagged in this game is complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  Once you get snagged, often for no reason, the hook is stuck forever and the only way to retrieve it is to turn up your drag and yank repeatedly until the hook comes out. 9/10 times the line breaks and you lose line and a lure.-this is a free-to-play game that has a leveling system and premium currency.  That means a lure you want requires real money to get (just use that money to get an actual lure and go fishing) and you can't fish for what you want to fish for since 1. some of the starting map's fish and all other fish from other lakes require a "license" that costs money and 2. equipment required to catch fish may be unavailable until you reach a certain level.  I guess this is a simulator because you literally pay for lures, line, rods, reels, bait, and everything else you could fish with in real life.-fishing, in real life, is rarely consistent.  Fish will change feeding habits and locations without warning.  Then why does fishing planet have tutorials where you can catch fish in the same spot again and again?As a game? Hmm....-as i said before, the free-to-play model is♥♥♥♥♥♥and I don't want to give them money.  TheHunter, a game with a similar business model, is actually good with this and I gladly give them my money.  For some reason, it has worse reviews due to the free-to-play model.  That makes zero sense.-The gameplay mechanics are broken.  Fishing in real life is more exciting.-Say you have the license to fish for something you'd want to catch...There is NO information how to fish for species.  NONE.  You have to google it just to know where exactly to cast and what bait to use.Plus, it sounds like they are banning people with negative things to say on forums? I haven't experienced this but it sounds shady.quit this and play TheHunter or better yet,  The Witcher 3. That game is dope.  0/10

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
Early Access Review
								Firstly, let me clear something up, I am not a fan of fishing in real life or in a game. However, that does not mean I have not enjoyed the good things this game has had to offer, and it was surprising that I have enjoyed the game as much as I have.Pros:-The game has a very relaxing atmosphere, beautiful environment and great gear and fish to experience in different weather, along with a satisfactory amount of locations (would like to see more though, much more)-The battles you have when you finally get a fish on the line can be pretty epic, and the disappointment when you lose one equally as epic and heartbreaking, but enjoyable none the less and a large reason of why the game can be so enjoyable.-Managing your gear setups, and having the right gear for the right fish and situation, really defines this game from a point of view of what makes this a strong game and as close to a simulation as one might imagine of a real life fishing experience in that regard.-Now (last update) you can see your friends fish as they have added the ability to see other people fishing in the same room. Yet to decide how this feature sits with me, but for now it’s been fine.-New Dynamic Fishing system, so you have to go and search out the fish, unlike before where they were static and predictably always in the same locations.-The feeling of when you catch something rare or big, such as a new personal record this can be very exciting. Sadly, these moments become less and less frequent the more you play the game, nevertheless this is something that makes you go back for more.-Helping each other out, friends and even strangers happy to help out with tips and tricks to catch certain types of fish, it is nice that people share information to help each other catch more fish more frequently.Cons:-The Grind, initially you have a reasonably decent progression, and you get new things, get new types of fish, unlock new locations and all seems to be going ok. Then as you level up to higher levels, though not the highest, more like between early and mid-levels. You realize how much of a grind you have ahead of you, just to unlock a new thing like a new area, new gear and new fish types. The grind is brutally painful.-Premium unlike some games where you can earn a premium status, this game requires real money transaction as the only way to get yourself into a premium status. Very Money driven new implementations in last update. And premium people get more game currency and xp rewards, so It makes it less grindy experience if you pay for it. And after every ingame day, the game reminds you of your status as premium or not. Just to let you know how important it is to have premium. This new feature really pisses me off.-Last update has increased the costs of things across the board, while the ratio to earnings was reduced. So the gap was increased. The game was already out of balance in this regard, now it is more so. Coupled with the fact that catching fish is more challenging now, it simply means more grind, for both pay and free players.-"Fast forward time" while fishing now isn’t just a simple necessary feature, no they decided to try and monetise it by adding a cooldown. So when you fill your bag after a day’s fishing and need/must forward time, you can find yourself waiting around doing nothing for the cooldown to run out because they forgot that if your bag is full you shouldn’t have to wait for a stupid cooldown to go home for the night to come back the next day. And if you do pay to have premium, you don’t even skip the cooldown, you simply reduce the cool down. This feature was incredibly badly thought out and implemented and should be reverted back to how it was.-The new system of lure fishing doesn’t seem to show properly, it was supposed to be fixed, but it still only works randomly. And furthermore to this, some of the other techniques like twitching seem to be broken now, so hopefully they can fix these things. Also the Fishing Rod Physics are now bugged in latest release which also needs fixing. Don't know why they update the game with bugs as clear as this, worked fine prior to update, makes no sense why they would break it and release it broken.-Licenses last a real life day. Instead of a game day. This is so ridiculous. If you only have 30 mins to fish one night, well too bad you pay for a full license. The costs really add up and hurt, the game is not friendly to casual players. It is heavily trying to stimulate long play sessions so that you might actually get some value from your playtime. Otherwise you can find yourself losing money, because of the stacking costs of Licenses. You could basically end up in scenario where you spend 5 or more in real life days fishing just one day in the game, however you have to pay for 5 Days’ worth of Fishing license. Simply makes no sense.-If you make enough money in a day, but don't have enough before going to your trip to cover the costs of the 2nd day, yes you pay to fish in game daily in addition to licenses. The game simply boots you back home, essentially losing the benefit of being out fishing. So even if you made say 10k and have plenty of fish, the game doesn't know to use what you caught to pay for the next day, watch out for this, it is really annoying when it first happens to you. It will simply force you home, even though you made more than enough to cover the costs. The message says "Stay ended" your stay on the pond has ended, you don't have enough money to stay longer. But you do, the game is just so badly made, that it won't recognize it. Really infuriating.-Lack of an audio cue for when you need to strike, (as an optional feature, would be great) because it really can be rather sad at times, that I have to sit there staring at a float all day hoping for a bite. Would be nice to be able to look at something else and have an audio queue when I need to strike and reel in the fish. Visual only cue is a bit limiting of times I’m willing to play the game. As it does take a certain amount of focus, an audio cue would really allow people to do other things while not missing out on catching the fish, because they are forced to stare at the float intently.Summary:Barely Recommending this, the game has its moments and it is free (time is money so the term free is used loosely in this case), so it is worth at least giving it a chance. You can have some relaxing moments and some excitement too all in one, but I do find I have to be in a specific mood to play this and I have to allow enough time to make it worthwhile. If you are into fishing, then It would make sense that you like this game. And if you are not, give it a try, who knows you might learn something, I know I did.

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								It's so close to being a good game that I wish I could give it a neutral rating instead of a Good or bad rating. The Good: The graphics and physics of the game are well done. The environments look and sound really good, lots of realism and depth. When you catch and reel in a fish it seems like one of the more realistic games I've played. There are a number of places you can fish and a number of species to fish for making it very diverse in the long run for someone that has reached the max level and unlocked / bought all the gear available to them. The Bad:  Your ability to enjoy this game is completely dependant upon your willingness to spend REAL money, and how much you're willing to spend. It's also dependant upon you being able to grind. If all you did was play the free version of the game, it's not enjoyable. It's boring, too much of a grind to ever really be fun. You waste too much in-game currency traveling back and forth between bodies of water as you level up. It also limits the amount of in-game cash you can earn by the size of your stringer, which is expensive to upgrade so it's a catch-22 getting out of low level, boring areas unless you open your REAL wallet and spend REAL money on one or all of the 3 things this game pretty much forces you buy. In game you have 2 currencies: A cash currency and a baitcoin currency. Cash is spent on average gear, baitcoins are spent on high-end gear. Both of the in-game currencies can be farmed by grinding (spending hours fishing while knowing where to fish, what to fish for, and what to fish with), OR you can skip the grind and just use real, hard-earned money to buy the currencies. The cash is cheaper than the baitcoins. Of course, this is how all free-to-play games make their money. For you to enjoy the game at the highest level you'll be spending a fair amount of REAL money on a regular basis. The game baits you into spending money on yet another near-necessity if you plan on playing a lot: A Premium Account!  A premium account allows you to grind through levels (40 of them) at a 50% increased rate over someone that has a regular account. Lets not forget that you also  make in-game cash about 50% quicker. The premium account monthly subscription is $14.99 per month, the cost of a WoW subscription. And then if you plan on bouncing back and forth between lakes fishing for "fun" fish and buying "good" gear you're going to be burning a hole in your real wallet paying for in-game currencies to make that happen. Why? Because the game charges you THOUSANDS of in-game dollars to travel to a particular body of water, but you cannot recover the thousands you spent in a single trip. So if you leave the lake, with a stringer of, say, $1,000 worth of fish, you have essentially lost money fishing there. How do you recover that money? By fishing the starter lake, which is little more than a pond, for HOURS until you've made enough to afford another trip! Or, <suprise suprise> You can just use your credit card to buy some cash to get out of the little pond in Texas and do some real fishing. Imagine that!  PAY TO WIN ladies and gentlemen. Those who pay to play will leave the average player in the dust and enjoy fishing more bodies of water for more species and sizes of fish. Its just that simple. SERVER DISCONNECTS AND CLIENT FREEZES I just had a server disconnect while reeling in maybe the biggest fish I have ever caught.  In 6 hours of playing I've had more than a few server disconnects and client freezes. It's not my computer. I have a custom gaming PC that I keep updated and CLEAN! I have a 300 Mbps connection, a Nighthawk router, and my NIC is a PCI-E Wireless AC1900 card with 3 high-gain antenna. In almost every game I play my ping is lower than just about everyone I play with and it's rock-solid steady. How this could be better: Stop charging people in-game currency to travel back and forth between bodies of water! I understand, and even like, spending in-game currency on gear. That makes sense to me. But this is a video game. It shouldn't feel like WORK to have to grind out money just so you can go fish where you want to fish.  And also: Fix the server instability issues.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played a bit and I think I understand enough to write a review. Here's the skinny: First off you don't have to pay a dime for anything to enjoy this game. It has, by far, the best payment model of any free to play game i've played. You don't have to spend a dime on anything. Ever. Everything sold as DLC is also sold in the shop. This does not mean that buying DLC is bad. You get some real bonuses for buying DLC. The number one bonus being that if you buy a DLC package then your rod/reel can never fully break. Second most important bonus is that you can repair most of the DLC items with in game credits instead of in game gold. Now, before you trip on the Gold/Cash thing this is where the payment model shines. You can earn gold in game and it's not hard or impossible. Flat out, not a pay to win by any means of the phrase. Gameplay: It is skill based. Also, being good means having knowledge.Last is the community. Nobody will tell you to, "Die Pleb" or "Roll out, Noob." Everyone is there to help everyone else.

								I have been pc gaming for 30 years, at least.  Last time I had played a game so addictive was when the first silent hunter came out.  Let me be plain about it.. this is the best game , of any genre , i have played in many years. content:
Posted: February 18
Early Access Review
								Fishing planet is a realistic sport fishing simulator that places players on the muddy shores of locations scattered across America. Cast your line into gentle waters and reel in a variety of fish, using patience and practical knowledge to successfully bag them. A huge assortment of gear is available to purchase; customize your loadout to catch particular fish, using the right rods, bait, and line to make the catch. Earn experience from every fishing trip and level up, unlocking new areas of the map, and earning money to purchase more equipment. Catch trophy-sized fish and rise to the top of the leaderboards, showing off your dedication and perseverance.Fishing Planet has amazing graphics. It is still in the 'Early Access' stage on Steam but has a ton of potential to be the best fishing game ever made. It needs better documentation and fine-tuning of game controls, physics, etc. But even though it's not finished yet, it's fun to play. It's free to play, with lots of extras available for optional purchase. No forced underwater views, plenty of real-life fishing spots, a ton of tackle/baits, and a wide variety of fish provide lots of replay value.Fishing Planet Key Features: + 32 Fish Species:  A huge assortment of fish swim in the waters of Fishing Planet, from Catfish to Pike.+ 7 Locations: Travel across North America and fish in varied environments, taking advantage of weather conditions to reap the largest number of fish you can.+ Huge Equipment Loadout: Purchase new gear and equipment to make fishing easier, opening up new opportunities.+ Leaderboards: make the biggest catch and rise to the top of the leaderboards.+ Relaxing Atmosphere: Immerse yourself in a soothing atmosphere and relax while fishing.Pros: +Realistic simulator +Large customization options +In-depth parameter choicesCons: -Long load times-Lackluster tutorial-Some random crashesMy Rating - "Good" Traditional Rating - 6.5/10Try it out as its free to play on steam.
